content: mallard duck pattern materials needed 2 25 mm hook yarn needle stuffing pins and blocking mat/piece of cardboard black embroidery thread 1mm craft wire 2 inches per duck * fabric glue i use hi-tack * *glue and wire are to make the beak these are recommended but optional an alternative crocheted beak pattern is also provided yarn 4 ply cotton yarn yarn brands i recommend scheepjes catona this yarn comes in 10g balls so is good for purchasing small amounts of multiple colours yarn and colors must have these yarns are almost identical so can both be used on the same duck you can use any yarn and hook but i would recommend using a natural fibre e g wool or cotton so that you can block the wings to form a point i would also suggest using the smallest comfortable hook for neat and tight stitches colours needed male mallard female mallard dark green medium brown white white dark brown blue grey orange i use a bright shade of orange for the white feet and tangerine shade for the beak blue bright orange yellow abbreviations single_crochet single_crochet half_double_crochet half_double_crochet double_crochet double_crochet htc half triple crochet tc triple crochet increase increase slip_stitch slip_stitch decrease decrease blo back loop only special stitches decrease in blo use a regular decrease not an invisible decrease insert hook into first back loop pull up a loop insert into next back loop pull up a loop yarn over and pull through all three loops slip_stitch in blo you will make slip stitches into the back loop only of both single_crochet and slip_stitch rounds when working into the back loop only of a round of slip stitches work into the back loop of the slip_stitch only one loop <centred single_crochet increase> this will create an increase that is centred over two stitches insert the hook into the same stitch as the previous single_crochet pull up a loop insert the hook into the next stitch and pull up a loop yarn over and pull through all three loops note that the next single_crochet will be worked into the same stitch as the centred single_crochet increase finished on how to use this pattern pattern uses us terms do not join rounds use a stitch marker to mark the beginning of the round wire beak recommended cut a 6cm length of 1mm wire and and 30cm of yarn of yellow yarn fold wire into a narrow u shape and add a tiny bit of fabric flue to the tip wrap the middle of the yarn around the tip approximately 3 times pinch the wire closer together to form the beak shape and wrap one end of the yarn around the two ends of wire and the remaining yarn tail approximately 6 times add a tiny amount of glue onto the wire as you go to hold this in place trim the wire so it sticks out the same length as the wrapped wire leave the tails long see pictures
